params.question: How do you define a blockchain? Which of the following statements are correct?

answers.text: As the ordered list of all transactions since inception
As a well-ordered set of blocks
As a block of transactions
As a well-ordered set of data, on which all peers eventually agree on
As a shared real-time transaction network

params.question: In the context of blockchain, what is the most fundamental definition of a transaction?

answers.text: A transmission of a message between nodes
An atomic event that is allowed by the underlying protocol
Exchange of a hash table between two peers

params.question: Choose all applicable properties of a Hash.

answers.text: A hash is deterministic, in that, calculating it twice yields the same result
A small change in the original value yields a smaller change in the hash than a big change in the original value
The probability of finding 2 different values that compute to the same hash is extremely low

params.question: What would be an instance of double-spending?

answers.text: The attacker sends 2 different transactions at the same time to the network, in order to send the same coin to 2 different recipients before the nodes can spot the fraud.

The attacker sends the coin to a recipient in exchange for a consideration, then waits to receive the consideration to then build a fork that does not contain the previous transaction and that is acceptable to the network.
The attacker sends the coin to a recipient in exchange for a consideration, then waits to receive the consideration to then send another transaction to cancel the first transaction.

params.question: How does Blockchain, as a non hierarchical approach, overcome the potential failures of a “classical” network?

answers.text: By making sure that every participant always has access to enough data to verify the integrity of ALL the data in the network.
By encrypting ALL data in the network.
By using certificates for all participants in the network, thus excluding malicious participants from the network.

params.question: What does a transaction do in a blockchain environment?

answers.text: Update one table on one machine
Update separate tables of accounts for the whole network

params.question: In Blockchain, what is the truth, i.e. true state?

answers.text: The truth is what Satoshi Nakamoto says
The truth is what the developer community agrees on
The truth is what the biggest miner considers the truth
The truth is the set of data that all participants eventually agree on

params.question: What is the Byzantine General's Problem?

answers.text: How to distribute data in a hierarchy-free, permission-less and failure-prone network
How to transmit data in a hierarchy-free, permission-less and failure-prone network
How to reach consensus in a hierarchy-free, permission-less and failure-prone network
How to find peers in a hierarchy-free, permission-less and failure-prone network

params.question: In the context of blockchain, what is the most fundamental definition of a transaction?

answers.text: A transmission of a message between nodes
An atomic event that is allowed by the underlying protocol
Exchange of a hash table between two peers

params.question: How does blockchain technology provide better ledger integrity?

answers.text: Blockchains can never be changed once data has been added
In order to change a piece of data in the past, all following blocks have to be recalculated

params.question: In a PoW network, for a malicious node to remove or insert transactions it would need to update the root hash of the containing block's Merkle tree, update the nonce of the containing block, update the hash of the containing block, and do the same for all subsequent blocks. Under what circumstances is that possible?

answers.text: If the attacker issues a high number of transactions
If the attacker controls more than 50% of the mining power in a blockchain network

params.question: Select all answers that are true for proof-of-work!

answers.text: Any node can propose new blocks
Potential miners must get approval by the network before they can propose blocks
More than one miner can find a correct block in the same time

params.question: What is the difficulty in a blockchain network?

answers.text: The difficulty determines how likely it is for a miner to find a valid block
The difficulty sets the fees a user has to pay for a transaction
The difficulty sets how difficult it is for clients to connect to the network

params.question: Select all answers that are true for proof-of-stake!

answers.text: Anyone can propose new blocks, irrespective of the number of coins/tokens held
Miners with a large stake in the network can propose blocks
More than one miner can find a correct block in the same time
The hypothesis for PoS suggests that participants with a large stake are more trustworthy

params.question: Why does one talk about eventual consensus in context of blockchain networks?

answers.text: It might take time for all nodes to agree on the substance and order of data
It might take time until the approval authority verifies the consensus

params.question: Identify the core characteristics of public blockchain networks.

answers.text: Publicly accessible
Guaranteed transaction privacy
Hierarchy-free
Using crypto-economic incentives
Using a central clearing house for all transactions

params.question: What does full decentralisation in public networks mean? Choose the right answer:

answers.text: It means that decentralised public networks provide access only to approved participants
It means that decentralised public networks are fully accessible

params.question: How are changes in public blockchain protocols verified?

answers.text: Changes are verified by a government entity
Changes are validated by community members
Changes are verified by core developers

params.question: How can public blockchain networks defend against malicious behaviour?

answers.text: By enforcing revocable access rights
By introducing game theoretic elements

params.question: What is the difference between a public and a private blockchain network?

answers.text: Public networks always use a different consensus algorithm
Public networks are controlled by the SEC unlike private networks
Private networks restrict user access unlike public networks

params.question: Which of the following statements about permissioned blockchains are true:

answers.text: In permissioned blockchains an individual or group of participants holds the authority to validate blocks
Permissioned blockchains restrict the actor's involvement regarding the consensus state
In permissioned blockchains smart contract creation is open to all network members

params.question: Why do managed blockchains not have to mitigate the Byzantine General's Problem?

answers.text: Because managed blockchains do not use any consensus algorithm
Because managed blockchains operate in a predictable environment with elements of authority and hierarchy
Because managed blockchains do not use proof-of-work as a consensus algorithm

params.question: Compared to public blockchains, which are open to everyone and do not have entry barriers, in managed blockchains accessibility can be decided by:

answers.text: A central authority
All participants which belong to the network
Everyone in- and outside of the network

params.question: Identify advantages of managed blockchain networks

answers.text: Public accessibility
Better scalability
Limited participation
Decentralised governance

params.question: What are the key reasons for managed/private networks to exist?

answers.text: To open the door to complex calculations
To protect confidential data
To increase network performance and reduce transaction times

params.question: Why can ledger integrity in financial infrastructures be improved with blockchain technology?

answers.text: Because managed networks have integrated alert systems in case of inconsistencies
Because each function execution is signed with a private key and every addition to the ledger constitutes a state change

params.question: Why is change management so important for blockchains?

answers.text: Because there is no central authority in blockchains
Because an unmanaged client update can have disastrous implications

params.question: What is Tezos?

answers.text: A P2P, open-source blockchain protocol
A decentralised data base
An oracle to fetch blockchain data

params.question: What was Tezos first protocol upgrade?

answers.text: Athens
Babylon
Carthage
Edo

params.question: What was the name of the first blockchain protocol?

answers.text: Bitcoin
Ethereum
Hyperledger Fabric
Corda

params.question: Why is maintaining a secure P2P networks a challenge?

answers.text: Because of the central authority managing the network
[x} Because of the potential for remote exploits
Because of interconnectivity

params.question: What are main attributes of DPoS? Please select the correct ones!

answers.text: Nodes proof their ammount of work by fulfiling a task of arbitrary difficulty
There is a fixed set of validators
Witnesses secure the network
Delegates are selected based on their stake to supervise network governance

params.question: What of the following are properties of a smart contract?

answers.text: Self-evolving
Self-executing
Self-enforcing
Self-verifying
Self-writing

params.question: How does Tezos amend its protocol, i.e. introduces change?

answers.text: Through its on-chain governance
Through hard forks
Through updates from their core developers

params.question: Which are stages of the Tezos amendment process? Please select!

answers.text: the proposal period
the exploration vote period or testing_vote period
the testing period
the promotion vote period
the adoption period

params.question: In Tezos, when do bakers vote on-chain?

answers.text: during the end of the proposal period
during the testing period
during the testing_vote period
during the promotion vote period
during the adoption period

params.question: What is the consensus mechanism in Tezos called?

answers.text: PoW
DPoS
PoS
LPoS

params.question: What is a baker?

answers.text: A validator node
A mining node
A delegate node
